title: What's changed since Worldcoin rebranded to World Network?

rawLines.text: thiago thank you very much for joining
us here on Crypto World thank you so
much for having me great to finally do
this in person and I'm sure you have
been very busy as chief product officer
for tools for humanity which is a key
contributor to Worldcoin now known as
World and we'll talk all about those new
developments in just a bit but first I
want to focus on the topic of privacy
last time we spoke was about exactly a
year ago and we spoke extensively about
this topic as several countries
including Spain and Portugal placed
temporary bans on what we see here that
controversial iris scanning device
called an orb and Hong Kong another
example forcing World Coin now known as
World to cease operations in the region
so I'm wondering what's going on right
now with all of that i believe Hong Kong
still doesn't allow world to operate in
the region and I understand I read
recently that Tools for Humanity
actually filed a lawsuit against Spain
for not complying with the rest of the
EU and working with authorities there
for over a year so despite that still no
resolution there what can you tell us
what's the latest so I think first it's
very important to understand that there
is no ban for worldcoin anywhere uh
generally anywhere where we operate
where you can go and verify an orb we're
always working with the authorities to
make sure that they understand what is
happening uh and that they do that even
before we launch now the project
sometimes grows so much on a given
country that the government has to go in
and make sure that what we're saying of
how the system works is actually in fact
how it does most of the times they can
do that while we continue operating
every once in a while like in some of
the examples that you've mentioned the
governments will actually ask us to
pause while they're able to review that
before we can return to operations right
so for example in the case of Portugal
uh we're back operating in Portugal and
so some of these cases take a little bit
longer than others but in general every
time we've gone through this process
with a with a government they verify
that in fact what we say is true which
is your data gets deleted from the orb
uh only you have access to your data and
you can use world ID fully anonymously
and what's the latest with Spain i don't
know if you are allowed to even talk
about it given there's a lawsuit in the
mix but what's the latest there is it in
fact operational again so the truth is I
personally don't know i focus only on
building our products and like making
sure they reach the people uh so I
honestly don't know what's the latest
with that now when we spoke last year it
seemed like we saw all these headlines
all the time about these privacy
concerns different regions banning these
orbs but now it seemed to have subsided
a bit so clearly Tools for Humanity is
doing something right but I did see
something recently involving Brazil
authorities there deciding to uphold its
restrictions on crypto compensation tied
to the World ID project and it also
decided to not accept the petition from
tools for humanity for their request to
see that ban so what exactly is going on
with Brazil and what are you doing to
quell some of the privacy concerns tied
to these orbs yeah so again I think as
you say we've been growing a lot right
uh over the past year and launching a
lot of new countries all over Europe
Latin America Asia and I think it's
normal that some of these will have more
questions than others uh so without
getting into Brazil specifically I think
I'm just really excited that just over
the last four months the network has
almost doubled in size uh and so we're
seeing unprecedented levels of growth
not just for crypto but for a consumer
product like this one this is something
that is needed right now in the world uh
consumers understand that companies
understand that regulators understand
that and we're seeing huge support from
all over the world um to get this done
does that have to do with the fact that
you went through a rebrand instead of
Worldcoin now the project is known as
World and with that came an updated iris
scanning orb which we see right here so
how is this orb different than the
original yeah so this orb is meant to
make it much more accessible for
everyone around the world right uh one
of the things that we think a lot about
is how do we put an orb within 15
minutes of any person that wants to
verify right and so this orb is not only
a lot easier to manufacture so it allows
us to make more of them but it has a
couple of cool new features that make it
more approachable for people the first
one is this one actually we can put on
stands on place like convenience stores
or malls just like an ATM without a
person next to it so you can simply walk
up to one of these orbs and in what we
call self-s serve you can connect your
phone to it and then your phone guides
you through the process so that just
like a photo booth at a mall you can
yourself uh get verified the other cool
thing you will be able to do with this
orb is what we call orb on demand which
is like right from your home or from
your work you can simply go on an app
and say you know what I want to get
verified right now and then a driver
will come to you with this orb will
verify you all your data gets deleted
and then the driver leaves and so a lot
of what we've been thinking about is to
make sure that this network is able to
reach as many people as possible is we
want to make the orbs as accessible as
possible and where do these upgraded
orbs exist currently yes so these ones
are actually about to go live into the
world we showed a preview of them uh
last November and we announced that in
the first half of this year they would
go into production so we're gearing for
that uh and hopefully very soon you'll
start seeing them pop up all over the
world now we have seen some competition
pop up one example that comes to mind is
the humanity protocol they actually use
palm scans instead of iris scans what's
your reaction to the fact that now
there's competition in the mix
essentially what they're trying to do is
to ensure real humans participate in
online spaces as opposed to bots which
is of course a huge goal for tools for
humanity so what's your reaction to all
of this competition and how does worlds
compare to the competition look I think
that when we started working on this
almost six years ago it was very
controversial to say that AI was going
to break down the internet and that we
were going to need to be able to tell
between a human and a bot we've really
believed back back then uh and I think
we've started seeing all of that play
out right whether you uh go to online
gaming and you're trying to play but
someone is shooting with bots or you go
to dating apps and you all of a sudden
realize that the person you're talking
to has six fingers and it was not
actually a person uh or Taylor Swift
puts out her concert tickets and uh they
all go to bots i think now we're all
understanding the importance of being
able to tell what is a human what is a
bot uh we've been working on the project
for more than five years we've tested
many different ways and we after all of
that time we really think the thing that
is the most privacy preserving the thing
that's the most secure and that is
inclusive that you can actually scale
across the world is something like the
orb so we're super comfortable with that
so you're not deterred by any of this
competition at all not at all i think if
anything we're really excited to see
that other people are realizing that
this is a big issue uh and we're very
confident that this is the right way to
solve it now when we spoke back in April
of last year there was a big
announcement at the time involving a new
L2 blockchain called WorldChain well 6
months later in October that blockchain
officially launched so now that it has
been a few months how's it going so far
is there a demand for this blockchain
and how are verified humans prioritized
over bots on this blockchain yes so
WorldChain has been a huge success uh we
launched it in October after announcing
it earlier last year and it is now
already the second largest uh Ethereum
layer 2 uh out there by user operations
which is just crazy really excited to
see that all of the people that are
joining the world network are not just
joining but they're actually sticking
around and they're using a bunch of
applications that developers are
building every single day and the cool
thing about these apps is that unlike
other things in crypto which are very
focused on power users or crypton native
users like myself which is great most
apps on
WorldC they're focused on actually being
simple enough and useful enough for
people in their real day-to-day lives so
these are things like being able to take
out a loan or being able to do payments
across the world uh and so we're very
excited by how that's going and in big
part we think it's gone well because
World Chain has a couple of tricks up
its sleeve because you're able to verify
as a real human we're able to give
priority to humans on the blockchain so
what that means in practice is that when
you do a transaction that transaction
gets pushed to the front of the line
it's almost like a VIP queue for humans
where all the other transactions from
bots have to go after you so even if the
network is congested at any point in
time like it happens with blockchain
sometimes the transactions for humans
always go through and the other one is
same thing for gas fees right a really
annoying thing about using blockchains
is that you have to pay a little bit for
every transaction but you actually have
to be depositing money to do that and
it's a bit of a pain and so with World
Chain well if you are verified human you
can simply use that blockchain for free
um which is great for users now you have
also been working on what's called World
Chat and I understand it's kind of like
a WhatsApp meets Venmo type thing and of
course it lives on the crypto wallet
world app which is on the blockchain
world chain so can you talk to me about
how this all works i also understand
that you can send and receive crypto and
stable coins like USDC using world app
so how does it all work and how did the
idea even come about to begin with
exactly so the way to think about it is
world app is a super app for humans in
the age of AI you can have your identity
there you have your wallet there and you
have your community meaning your
contacts and now all those things come
together into something called mini apps
which are third party applications that
you can run right inside of World App
and we have hundreds of developers
building these things and millions of
users using mini apps every day one of
these mini apps that we released earlier
this year is World Chat which is a
really cool application it's very simple
it's a chat app like WhatsApp but it has
a couple of interesting properties first
when you're talking with someone you can
know whether they're a verified human or
not and so that lets you know like hey
this is probably a scam and you should
be a little bit more careful because
this is not a verified human when
someone texts you but then also just
like you can attach a picture or a voice
message you can also attach money on a
message and so without needing to know
anything about crypto or blockchains or
gas or anything like that you can simply
say "Hey I want to send $10 to my friend
in Italy right now." And by tapping one
button in a single second without any
fees those $10 are now in Italy with
your friend and how can people feel
comfortable knowing that sending money
this way is in fact secure yes well
world app is a fully self-custodial
application that means that uh both the
keys for your wallet and the keys for
your world ID are sold locally only on
your device so only you have access to
that now world is also getting into the
gaming space partnering with a lifestyle
brand for gamers called Razer and the
goal is to help people engage in a
human-only gaming experience so how did
this partnership come about and how does
that work exactly yes so we've been
hearing for a while from not just gamers
but also gaming studios that they're
really concerned about about what bots
are doing to gaming uh we recently ran a
survey in the United States where more
than 70% of people report that bots are
ruining online gaming and the more
concerning things especially for studios
is that more than 20% of those gamers
have just stopped gaming because it's
not fun anymore and so we got together
with Razer which is obviously one of the
largest gaming companies in the world
they have hundreds of millions of users
around the world and they said "Well
what if we use World ID to be able to
enable things like gaming servers that
are only for humans or specific
tournaments that are only for humans or
maybe you can have items in your games
that are exclusive for humans to start
incentivizing people to verify and so we
announced that two weeks ago the
reaction from the community has been
amazing and there's already uh one
committed game coming out it's called
Tokyo Beast that is coming out in a few
weeks uh that will be supporting World
ID hopefully there will be many more
like that in the future so obviously
world is getting into gaming but what
else can people expect from worlds what
else is in the pipeline you mentioned
dating apps earlier as an example can we
see verification for dating apps for
example through world so I think that in
the midterm and the long term you will
use world ID for every single thing you
do on the internet whether you're
talking about social networks right
where like clearly paying $8 a month
doesn't solve the problem of bots uh
dating apps concert tickets financial
services where the financial companies
need to know whether they're giving that
loan to a real human or to someone
that's using AI to defraud them right
every single thing we do on the internet
uh relies on trust and for that trust to
exist you have to know whether something
is a human or a bot and so World ID
solves that and it solves this in a way
in which you can remain anonymous as you
do all of these things
last question for you what was the main
reason behind the rebrand back in
October from worldcoin to world did
those privacy concerns and all the
headlines tied to worldcoin did that
play a role in the rebrand at all what
was the impetus behind that move so the
the rebrand was very simple right uh the
world coin token actually still exists
right uh but there's as the project has
grown there's more been more and more
pieces that have gotten uh released
things like world ID for you to be able
to verify on the internet things like
world chain things like world app things
like world chat and so it just made
sense that the network overall would be
called world while each of the pieces uh
was a subset of that and so it's simply
just a reflection of how the project has
grown how the mission has continued to
get expanded uh and so that's why we
were really excited to announce the
updated brand Thiago Sada chief product
officer with Tools for Humanity thank
you very much for joining us here on
Crypto World in Studio thank you Swami
